intro: Clinopodium vulgare subsp. orientale, commonly known as oriental mint, is a perennial herb native to parts of Asia and the Middle East. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with opposite, ovate to lanceolate leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Its small, tubular flowers are usually pink or purple and are arranged in whorled clusters at the ends of the stems. The aromatic qualities of the leaves make it a valuable plant in traditional medicine and culinary uses.
